newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian soda ash industry wants ban on U.S. group.
newsitem.headline: Indian soda ash industry wants ban on U.S. group.

text.p: Indian soda ash makers on Monday demanded a ban on imports from U.S. firms, saying their competitors had formed a cartel that could destroy the Indian industry with low prices.

The Alkali Manufacturers Association of India (AMAI) said members of the American Natural Soda Ash Corporation (ANSAC) were underpricing their products in the Indian market to wipe out the local competitors.
AMAI comprises Tuticorin Alkalies Chemicals and Fertilisers Ltd, Birla VXL, Gujarat Heavy Chemicals, DCW LTD, Punjab National Fertilisers, Tata Chemicals Ltd and Saurashtra Fertilisers.

Singh said ANSAC, the international marketing arm for six U.S. producers, exported 23,000 tonnes of soda ash to India last September at a price that was nearly 900 rupees per tonne ($25), or about 12 percent, lower than the Indian domestic price.
"The price at which they exported to India cannot be sustained by any individual producer over a long period of time," Mehan said.
Soda ash is a basic raw material for the manufacture of glass, detergents and paper. ANSAC produces nearly 30 percent of world's soda ash, industry officials said.
"We are not protesting against imports from individual producers. It is the cartel that we are opposing," Singh said.
Tata Chemicals vice president Kapil Mehan said Indian producers could be driven out of business by a flood of cheap imports.
He said if imports from ANSAC were not checked, nearly 145,000 workers could lose their jobs.
AMAI has taken the case to India's Monopolies and Restricted Trade Practices Commision (MRTPC) for a ruling.
There are six producers of soda ash in India and the total installed capacity is 1.865 million tonnes. In the year to March 31, 1997, domestic demand totalled 1.6 million tonnes. ($1=35.7 rupees)
